title: How to Use Any Two Handed Sword

steps.title: Grip your sword with your dominant hand (in this article it will be referred to as the right hand and the non-dominant as the left henceforth).
steps.content: Grip your sword with your dominant hand (in this article it will be referred to as the right hand and the non-dominant as the left henceforth). Switch this if you are left-handed) right below the guard and grab the pommel(bottom of the sword) with your left hand. If the pommel is very uncomfortable to grip, stick with the basic two hand grip. [1] X Research source

steps.title: With the left hand, grip the sword tightly with the pinky, ring, and middle finger, the others should have a semi-tight grip.
steps.content: With the left hand, grip the sword tightly with the pinky, ring, and middle finger, the others should have a semi-tight grip. The right hand is not used for striking! [2] X Research source

steps.title: Hold your sword so that the pommel is right above your bellybutton (don't rest it on the stomach, keep it a little ways out) and point the tip somewhere between the sternum and throat.
steps.content: Hold your sword so that the pommel is right above your bellybutton (don't rest it on the stomach, keep it a little ways out) and point the tip somewhere between the sternum and throat. Now if they charge full on they'll run into your weapon. [3] X Research source

steps.title: When striking, stab at the sky, bringing your left hand up past your eye, then come down on them, using your right hand to guide the blade and using the left hand to set the force in to the blade.
steps.content: When striking, stab at the sky, bringing your left hand up past your eye, then come down on them, using your right hand to guide the blade and using the left hand to set the force in to the blade. The right hand should be the axis or pivot.

steps.title: Now the footwork.
steps.content: Now the footwork. Place your left foot behind your right foot (other way around if you're left handed) and stand on the balls of your left foot. Keep your balance!

steps.title: When you strike, you push with your left foot, sliding your right foot on the ground and raise your sword.
steps.content: When you strike, you push with your left foot, sliding your right foot on the ground and raise your sword. Now bring your left foot back into position and STRIKE! [4] X Research source

steps.title: When striking, keep your right arm straight (but not locked, you don't want it broken) and bend it when it reaches your head.
steps.content: When striking, keep your right arm straight (but not locked, you don't want it broken) and bend it when it reaches your head. Reverse what you just did to strike, but remember, your strike with the hand closest to the pommel, you use your dominant hand to guide. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Practice your strikes.
steps.content: Practice your strikes. Don't weakly hit them, keep each and every swing full and powerful. Keep your battle cry strong (otherwise known as your kiai[kee-eye]) so your hit stays strong. After you are good at individual strikes, try them in a string, hit the gloves, then immediately advance to hit the head!

steps.title: Don't get set in your ways too much.
steps.content: Don't get set in your ways too much. If you go to get taught by a true swordsman, you will have to throw away all you thought you knew about armed combat and take every bit of knowledge from the trainer.

steps.title: And finally, DON'T GIVE UP!
steps.content: And finally, DON'T GIVE UP! If you want to be any sort of blades man you will have to practice daily. If you become rusty, you'll fall behind.
